title: EUTHEMIA
content:
EUTHEMIA was a nymph of the Aegean island of Kos (Cos) who insulted the goddess Artemis and was struck down by her arrows.

Euthemia was probably one of the Naiades--fresh-water nymphs that were believed to die if their springs dried
        up. Indeed the passage "snatched away alive by Persephone" suggests a spring lost beneath the earth.

Pseudo-Hyginus, Astronomica 2. 16 (trans. Grant) (Roman mythographer C2nd A.D.)
          :
        "[Meropes of Cos] had a wife, Ethemea, of the race of Nymphae (Nymphs), who was struck with the arrows of
        Diana [Artemis] when she ceased worshipping her. At last she was snatched away alive by Proserpina [Persephone]
        to the Land of the Dead."

A complete bibliography of the translations quoted on this page.
